ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Thumbs way up. Typical grad seminar set-up: class once a week, 500-word reading response to usually 200-400 pages of reading. Joanna is a gift to the Yale faculty. Those interested in STS, feminist theory, postcolonial theory, multispecies theory, and critiques of hegemonic epistemology needn't look further.
It is an excellent course that I would definitely recommend. However, one must be able to keep up with the reading material.
Good course, would recommend it. Workload is interesting, but lots of essays rather than fewer books, which makes for a lot of it.
The class goes over a number of theoretical and practical elements of STS. It was an excellent, though high level, introduction for someone not in the department.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: It provided perhaps the necessary grounding for even more advanced social studies in science and technology. It provides theoretical frameworks and important questions that are currently applied and pertinent to the field
Offered a range of tools to develop further and maybe put to use, too.
This course provided a new perspective for understanding my discipline since it was outside of my department.
